quoteFirst: I glanced at my watch. NO! The time was
quoteLast: He was coming at nine o'clock last night. . . .
title: Life Blood
author: Hoover, Thomas, 1941-

quoteLast: We find the sun very hot and scorching, but all try to keep out of it as much as we can.
title: The Man That Corrupted Hadleyburg, and Other Stories
author: Twain, Mark, 1835-1910

quoteFirst: Congratulations over, chairs are cleared away, rugs taken up and the room made ready for dancing till supper, Leschetizky playing for at least part of the evening. Toasts, speeches, stories, and laughter fill the hours till early morning, when,
quoteLast: , a happy, but exhausted, procession streams homeward, stopping on the way at some café--if it is not yet 6 o'clock--to make sure the hall-porter, with his dripping candle and everlasting demand for his ten-kreutzer fee, will be safely gone to his lair.
title: Theodor Leschetizky
author: Hullah, Annette

quoteLast: a small force including our regiment, moved down within about three quarters of a mile of the James river, formed line of battle and threw up rifle pits; remained here until about 4 o'clock p. m. when we were relieved by General Burnside's Division of colored troops.
title: Personal Recollections and Civil War Diary, 1864
author: Abbott, Lemuel Abijah, 1842-1911

quoteFirst: “Next morning, the 5th of March (a day to be remembered in the annals of the Thirteenth Hussars), we moved off
quoteLast: and proceeded up the Tigris, in the teeth of a terrible sand-storm, which blinded both horses and men, and through which we could only see 80 to 100 yards ahead of us. Suddenly, out to our front, we heard the sound of rifle-fire, and bullets whizzed amongst us.
title: The Thirteenth Hussars in the Great War
author: Durand, H. Mortimer (Henry Mortimer), 1850-1924

quoteFirst: It was freezing hard, and I fear the poor fellows wished me and my luggage no good when, after much striving, we were finally afloat, and they resumed their places at the oars. In the dark the great hull loomed gigantic as,
quoteLast: , we pulled alongside of the steamer, which turned out to be the _Iberia_, one of the largest and finest vessels of the Pacific Company, commanded by Captain Shannon.
title: Notes of a naturalist in South America
author: Ball, John, 1818-1889

quoteLast: , in this same ward from which all the rioters came, Stephen Harman broke everything he could lay hands on—the window frame and all its panes of glass, his cell table, stool, shelf, trencher, salt-box, spoon, drinking-cup, and all his cell furniture. He had first barricaded his door, and could not be secured till all the mischief was done.
title: Millbank Penitentiary: An Experiment in Reformation
author: Griffiths, Arthur, 1838-1908

quoteLast: , in this same ward from which all the rioters came, Stephen Harman broke everything he could lay hands on—the window frame and all its panes of glass, his cell table, stool, shelf, trencher, salt-box, spoon, drinking-cup, and all his cell furniture. title: Millbank Penitentiary: An Experiment in Reformation

quoteFirst: Lieutenant Macdowell, second in command of Hodson's Horse--an eye-witness--says: "The steadiness with which the cavalry confronted this most anxious position for two hours is as deserving of praise as the courage of the infantry who carried the breaches.  At three a.m. we moved down in column of squadrons to the rear of our batteries, and waited there till
quoteLast: , when the enemy advanced from the Lahore gate with two troops of artillery, no end of cavalry, and a lot of infantry, apparently to our front.  I think that they intended to try and take their old position now that we had got theirs.
title: Our Soldiers: Gallant Deeds of the British Army during Victoria's Reign
author: Kingston, William Henry Giles, 1814-1880

quoteFirst: The day of the Spank had a bad openin'. When Deedee woke up, along
quoteLast: , it was rainin' pitchforks, and that meant a day indoors, and to start off, she stood up in her crib and called for “laim.”
title: The Confessions of a Daddy
author: Butler, Ellis Parker, 1869-1937; Cory, Fanny Y., 1877-1972 [Illustrator]

quoteLast: . Saw a Sail under Our Lee Bow about a League Dist. all hands was Called upon Deck and Gott Ready to Receive her had she been an Enemy. We fired one of our Bow Chases and brot. him too. she was a Sloop from Nantuckett, Russell Mas'r.
title:
Privateering and Piracy in the Colonial Period
Illustrative Documents
author: Jameson, J. Franklin (John Franklin), 1859-1937 [Editor]

quoteFirst: By tokens and signs we found that both of us belong to that great body of men that knows each other as brothers in every corner of the inhabited world. It was he, Dr. Lucretius, who came to my cabin on the morning of the 16th of May, at
quoteLast: , and knocking at the door, said, Father Golden, we are now entering into the harbor of New York, and if you want to enjoy a grand view of the surrounding country you had better come out on the upper bridge. I shall be there waiting for you to explain some of the most beautiful sceneries that you have ever looked upon in your life.
title: Conversion of a High Priest into a Christian Worker
author: Golden, M. (Meletios)

quoteFirst: From Genoa he went to Leghorn and Pisa, from Pisa to Florence, thence to Sienna, and on to Rome. ‘I came to Rome on the 4th November, 1644,
quoteLast: , and being perplexed for a convenient lodging, wandered up and down on horseback, till at last one conducted us to Monsieur Petits, a Frenchman, near the Piazza Spagnola. Here I alighted, and having bargained with my host for 20 crownes a moneth, I caused a good fire to be made in my chamber and went to bed, being so very wet.
title: Sylva; Or, A Discourse of Forest Trees. Vol. 1 (of 2)
author: Evelyn, John, 1620-1706; Nisbet, John, 1853-1914 [Commentator]

quoteFirst: When they got there, however, they found they were drawing so much shell fire that the R.E. officer decided not to proceed with the work.
quoteLast: next morning the Battalion moved forward to support, relieving the Seaforth Highlanders, who replaced the Black Watch in the front line, the latter taking our place in the reserve. The position of the Battalion now was two Companies in the Trench immediately behind North Station Buildings, and one Company in the strong points.
title: The History of the 7th Battalion Queen's Own Cameron Highlanders
author: Sandilands, James Walter; MacLeod, Norman, 1872-1960

quoteLast: . (E.S.E., veering S.S.W.; o, m, r.) Bishop Rock L.H., April 21st, in numbers, along with Blackbirds, Ring Ouzels, and Wheatears, from midnight to 4 a.m. (E., 2; misty.
title:

quoteFirst: "_January 18._ Sights were taken in the night, and at
quoteLast: we turned out and marched from this night camp about 3¾ miles back in a S.E.ly direction to a spot which we judged from last night's sights to be the Pole. Here we lunched camp: built a cairn: took photos: flew the Queen Mother's Union Jack and all our own flags. We call this the Pole, though as a matter of fact we went ½ mile farther on in a S.
title: The Worst Journey in the World: Antarctic, 1910-1913
author: Cherry-Garrard, Apsley, 1886-1959

quoteFirst: Our pickets were stationed there, and the troops were furnished a lively greeting as they got off of the cars. After a good deal of fussing with the pickets, these troops entered the town
quoteLast: , and at 6 A.M., we moved off on the Litchfield road.
title: History of Morgan's Cavalry
author: Duke, Basil Wilson, 1838-1916

quoteFirst: at night, with Thrushes, Larks, and Starling; wind E., strong; rain, fog, snow (see Thrush); many killed. March 13th,
quoteLast: , ten killed striking; clear, wind E.; most of Blackbird killed were females. September 24th, 11 P.M., one killed striking.

title: Battery E in France: 149th Field Artillery, Rainbow (42nd) Division
author: Kilner, Frederic Richard, 1892-

quoteFirst: Lightened by the flames she floated off the bar and drifted, a huge pyramid of fire, down the river illuminating its broad expanse till all was bright as day, and revealing the shattered vessels of the fleet as they hastily steamed out of the way of their dangerous consort. Long after she had passed around the bend the light of the flames reflected on the sky marked her progress.
quoteLast: , when at almost the identical spot where the Confederate ram “Arkansas” was blown up, the fire reached the magazine and the “Mississippi” existed only in story. The shock of the explosion was felt at Port Hudson, twenty miles distant.
title: Company K, First Alabama Regiment; or, Three Years in the Confederate Service
author: Smith, Daniel P.
